body: @tornadomeet The indent of the code seems to be incorrect. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/fcn-xs/image_segmentaion.py#L6-L22

refer to
 'https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet-notebooks/blob/master/python/how_to/predict.ipynb'

@piiswrong @tqchen 
The problem reproduce after several batches as @sxjscience described.
It seems  it is caused by my modification of executor_manager.py I construct a new executor for each batch, and the old one will be deconstructed, as follows:
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/executor_manager.py#L399. 
```
        if self.sym_gen is not None:
            key = data_batch.bucket_key
            # create new bucket entry
            symbol = self.sym_gen(key)
            execgrp = DataParallelExecutorGroup(symbol, self.arg_names,
                                                self.param_names, self.ctx,
                                                self.slices, data_batch,
                                                shared_group=self.execgrp)
            # delay the deconstruct 
            # self.prev_execgrp = self.curr_execgrp
            self.curr_execgrp = execgrp_bucket
```
However when I remove the comment of ` self.prev_execgrp = self.curr_execgrp`, it will be ok.

When i compile mxnet in my win10 laptop，i get similar error ```self._handle = _dlopen(self._name, mode)
WindowsError: [Error 126]``` . I copy the files(```libgcc_s_seh-1.dll、libgfortran-3.dll、libopenblas.dll、libquadmath-0.dll```) in the prebuild mxnet (3rdparty\openblas\bin) to solve the problem, it works. People who meet the same problem can try  this.
The same solution worked for me as well on debian sid, gcc 6.2.0

Regarding 2: we could follow the approach used by a popular Caffe to TensorFlow converter: [Caffe to TensorFlow](https://github.com/ethereon/caffe-tensorflow/blob/0c5bf53817f89c7e4581ad6b738a4bb19eea96b3/kaffe/transformers.py#L209)

@piiswrong: `broadcast_mul` is not enough, as the Caffe `Scale` layer also has an optional learnable bias parameter, which gets used in resnet.
Any update on this? I still get the same problem
I will test it with GCC6 and fix this.

@thirdwing what you are suggesting is to implement a reference class from scratch that copies the behavior of the C++ iterator class?

I want to reimplement the method `value` in `mx.io.arrayiter`. So what you are suggesting is to do:

```R
cus_iter <-setRefClass("Custom.Iter", fields = c("data", "label","batch.size", "shuffle"))
cus_iter$methods(iter.next = function() {
#code here
})
cus_iter$methods(value = function() {
#code here
})
```
Could this class be used as an input to `mx.model.FeedForward.create`?

Ideally what I would like is to inhereit from a `MXArrayDataIter` and reimplement only the method `value`. If I create an instance of `mx.io.arrayiter`, it has everything that I want but I don't know how to modify the `value`.
```R
array.iter.mx <- mx.io.arrayiter(data = train.x, label = train.y, batch.size = 100, shuffle = TRUE)
is(array.iter.mx)
[1] "Rcpp_MXArrayDataIter" "C++Object"           
[3] "envRefClass"          ".environment"        
[5] "refClass"             "environment"         
[7] "refObject"
mxnet:::is.MXDataIter(array.iter.mx)
[1] TRUE
```
In python you can create a custom iterator if you inhereit from `mx.io.DataIter` and reimplement  `provide_data(), provide_label(), next()`. How can this be done in R?

I think you can try something like below:

```r
> setRefClass("Custom.Iter", contains = "Rcpp_MXArrayDataIter")
> 
> cus_iter <-setRefClass("Custom.Iter", contains = "Rcpp_MXArrayDataIter")
> cus_iter$methods(`iter.next` = function() {return(TRUE)})
> 
> cus_iter
Generator for class "Custom.Iter":

No fields defined

Class Methods: 
     "iter.next#Rcpp_MXArrayDataIter", "import", ".objectParent", 
     "usingMethods", "show", "getClass", "untrace", "export", ".objectPackage", 
     "callSuper", "copy", "initFields", "getRefClass", "trace", "field", 
     "iter.next", "num.pad", "reset", "value", "finalize", "initialize"

Reference Superclasses: 
     "Rcpp_MXArrayDataIter", "envRefClass"

> 
> it <- cus_iter$new()
> 
> it$iter.next()
[1] TRUE
```

The problem with that is that it's not taking the methods from the c++ class. The class has `value, reset`. We are  just creating `iter.next()` that every time is called it returns `TRUE` but it is not counting the number of batches. And it won't return a batch of values...

We then decided to use tf.python_io.TFRecordWriter for the time being.

@mli I got it, thanks for your help.

You are probably using a 32bit OpenCV and trying to compile a 64bit mxnet,
or vice versa. Make sure your OpenCV binary fits your chosen platform.

@tqchen @piiswrong @tornadomeet Hi, I encountered a similar problem when running the FCN example with `--retrain` argument. When I set `ctx` to `gpu(3)` (https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/fcn-xs/fcn_xs.py#L14), the error message I got is
`mxnet.base.MXNetError: [10:37:36] src/operator/operator_util.cc:886: Check failed: lhs.ctx() == rhs.ctx() operands context mismatch 2 3 vs. 1 0`
And with `ctx` set to `gpu(0)`, the message is "`... 2 0 vs. 1 0`".

Using `NaiveEngine`, I found the error comes from `self.updater(key, arr, self.arg_params[key])` (https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/fcn-xs/solver.py#L86). I was wondering why this happens and how it can be resolved.

@tqchen @piiswrong @tornadomeet I did another experiment of training FCN8s. When setting the `--retrain` argument with the provided `FCN8s_VGG16-0019.params`, the training run normally with `ctx` set to  `gpu(0)` and terminated with error with `ctx` set to `gpu(3)` (`... operands context mismatch 2 3 vs. 2 0`). Does this mean I have to use the same GPU ID for fine-tuning as that used in learning the pre-trained model? But this makes no sense and is not reasonable at all. Currently I can only train FCN from scratch with customized `ctx`.

some how like this
```python
conv1_1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv1_1', data=data , num_filter=64, pad=(1,1), kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False, attr={'lr_mult':'0.01'})
```
you can refer to http://shuokay.com/2016/09/02/transfer-learning/

@fungtion Is your mxnet package updated version? Since I have no problem to run your code. Also the traceback shows the exception position is in line 391 of io.py, which should be in line 397 in current version.

Another possible reason is your mxnet python path is not correctly set. It should be .../mxnet/python

I think you should bind the input and run forward manually like this:
```python
symbol, arg_params, aux_params = mx.model.load_checkpoint(model_path, epoch)                                                                                                                                                    
input_shape = dict([('data1', (1, 3, height, width)), ('data2', (1, 3, height, width))])                                                                                                                                                                           
network = self.get_predict_net()                                                                                                                                                                                                
executor = network.simple_bind(ctx=mx.cpu(), **input_shape)                                                                                                                                                                
executor.copy_params_from(arg_params, aux_params)
outputs = executor.forward(is_train=False, data1=mx.nd.array([some_data1]), data2=mx.nd.array([some_data2]))

```
Sorry that I misunderstood you. You should use `mx.symbol.MakeLoss`.
One option might be adding "lr_mult" entry to json file and load the modified json.

BlockGrad sets the gradient to 0, but you are still learning weight decay.
I suggest a "HowTo" label to this issue and change the subject to "How to freeze certain layers in finetune".

@precedenceguo Thanks for reply.

I found out that I did not understand the mechanism of opt.set_lr_mult() method.

The program would lookup the attributes in the whole network recursively when the 'set_lr_mult()' method was called.
If the variables did not have such attributes, nothing would be done. The weights would be updated with the original learning rate. In other words, the set_lr_mult() method took no effects.

I added the 'lr_mult' attributes to the variables in advance, and then installed the optimizer. Everything was OK then.

@back2yes , yes.
But I am not sure that the mxnet will always minimize the loss function. Because I find one `mx.metric.accuracy` which should be maximized.

`mx.metric` are not loss functions to optimize, but for evaluation.

In your case, MXNet minimized log_loss (If you choose SoftmaxOutput).
It follows that the accuracy score increases.

@mli

did you use prebuilt binaries? Binaries doesn't work for some versions of windows due to cuda dll compatibility issues.

See if it works with ctx=mx.cpu(0)

what function are you trying to implement?
MXNet has a different programming model. Graphs are static and loops are done imperatively by calling executor.forward()/backward() and call imperative apis on the result

Also please work with the nnvm branch (instead of master) since it will be released soon.

with nnvm branch all functions are available in both symbol and ndarray.
@tqchen I think this is the same problem as before. Executor can get destructed before ops pushed by the executor is finished
@zihaolucky Any progress?? :)

@piiswrong I think you are right on this. This can be fixed by changing https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/nnvm/src/executor/attach_op_execs_pass.cc#L156 to not use reference, or keep reference to the shared_ptr of the corresponding node

the first error seems to be `--gpus` is not given ascii input
the second probably due to the download of mnist is failed, please remove the the mnist data in `./data` and try it again
is it possible to fix it once and for all by making executor destruction async and depend on the operators it pushed?

there is no dependency for operations, but instead only on the variables. It will need a destruction depends on all the variables in the executor, and make the data structure internal.

Making the pushed operator self-conatained and store things by value is a finer grained approach to solve this problem

jenkins doesn't have osx. If you think its not an issue we can move it to

Wouldn't this be expensive since the calculations happens in Python, rather than on the GPU? Or is it that the whole operation in `sum([nd.norm(grad).asnumpy()[0]**2 for grad in params_grad.values()]))` is somehow pushed down to GPU?
@shivarajugowda The strategy is to use `nd.norm`, which is computed using GPU with cuBLAS, to get a scalar output and copy it to the CPU side and do the summation.
Also, my experience is that `nd.norm(x)`, which calls the BLAS API, is much faster than `nd.sqrt(nd.sum(nd.square(x)))`.

The reason I suggest using imperative API for norm-clipping is that it'll be much easier to debug the code and tune the hyper-parameters by visualizing the gradient norm. We've been using this trick for tuning recurrent neural networks.

@sxjscience I see, thanks for the clarification. So one dimension is executed in GPU and one in CPU. So if the overall operation is O(n^2). O(n) operations are called on the GPU in sequence for n times and the sum is accumulated on the CPU.
For example, if we have K parameter gradient. The code computes the norm(norm is a scalar) of each gradient on GPU and sum these K values on CPU.
@sxjscience got it, thanks.
